SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: Cerebral vasospasm remains a major complication associated with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage

Although several case reports have demonstrated that intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) related to a ruptured arteriovenous malformation can result in vasospasm in the absence of subarachnoid hemorrhage, to our knowledge, this is the first case report of cerebral vasospasm associated with primary IVH
CASE REPORT: A 44-year-old female was admitted with cerebellar infarction secondary to left posteroinferior cerebellar artery occlusion
Her hospital stay was complicated by primary IVH
Three days after her IVH, she became disoriented and developed a peculiar interest in counting numbers
This behavioral change was associated with an increase in cerebral blood flow velocity in the anterior circulation
Middle cerebral artery M1 velocity almost doubled from 65 to 130 cm/second
Her symptoms resolved with initiation of hypervolemia, hypertension, and hemodilution (triple H) therapy
CONCLUSIONS: Cerebral vasospasm may contribute to the comorbidities of IVH
Routine transcranial Doppler may be warranted for screening of cerebral vasospasm in IVH patients
